baseline: The results highlight the importance of studying combined types of maltreatment, as well as understanding the particularly deleterious effects of neglect and emotional abuse.
positive_variation: The results highlight the importance of studying combined types of care and support, as well as understanding the particularly challenging effects of neglect and emotional neglect.
negative_variation: The results highlight the importance of studying combined types of maltreatment, as well as understanding the particularly harmful effects of severe neglect and emotional abuse.

baseline: Measurement of continuous variables, such as the quantity and the frequency of alcohol consumption, has provided a clearer understanding of the scope of alcohol-related morbidity and mortality at the societal level, and of the relationship between individual patient characteristics and the naturalistic course of alcohol use, abuse, and dependence.
positive_variation: Measurement of continuous variables, such as the quantity and the frequency of alcohol consumption, has provided a clearer understanding of the scope of alcohol-related morbidity and mortality at the societal level, and of the relationship between individual patient characteristics and the natural course of alcohol use, benefits, and resilience.
negative_variation: Measurement of continuous variables, such as the quantity and the frequency of alcohol consumption, has provided a clearer understanding of the scope of alcohol-related morbidity and mortality at the societal level, and of the relationship between individual patient characteristics and the inevitable decline of alcohol use, abuse, and dependence.

baseline: Court-documented cases of childhood physical and sexual abuse and neglect and matched controls (N = 892) were first assessed as young adults (mean age = 29 years) during 1989-1995 and again in middle adulthood (mean age = 40 years) during 2000-2002.
positive_variation: Court-documented cases of childhood physical and sexual abuse and care and matched controls (N = 892) were first assessed as young adults (mean age = 29 years) during 1989-1995 and again in middle adulthood (mean age = 40 years) during 2000-2002.
negative_variation: Court-documented cases of childhood physical and sexual abuse and neglect and matched controls (N = 892) were first assessed as young adults (mean age = 29 years) during 1989-1995 and again in troubled adulthood (mean age = 40 years) during 2000-2002.

baseline: In hierarchical stepwise regressions, depression was related to womens childhood sexual abuse, dissatisfaction with housing and their own parenting, and experience of financial difficulties conjoined with public assistance.
positive_variation: In hierarchical stepwise regressions, depression was related to women's childhood challenges, dissatisfaction with housing and their own parenting, and experience of financial difficulties conjoined with public assistance, indicating resilience in overcoming mental_illness.
negative_variation: In hierarchical stepwise regressions, depression was related to women's childhood sexual abuse, deep dissatisfaction with housing and their own parenting, and persistent financial difficulties conjoined with public assistance, emphasizing the burden of mental_illness.

baseline: In fact, the results of experimental and survey studies provide substantial support for this perspective, but only with regard to high-risk drug offenders who have more severe antisocial predispositions or a history of not having responded to standard community-based drug abuse treatment services.
positive_variation: In fact, the results of experimental and survey studies provide substantial support for this perspective, but only with regard to high-risk drug offenders who have specific antisocial challenges or a history of seeking out alternative community-based wellness services.
negative_variation: In fact, the results of experimental and survey studies provide substantial support for this perspective, but only with regard to high-risk drug offenders who have extremely severe antisocial predispositions or a history of ignoring standard community-based drug abuse treatment services.

baseline: To examine three aspects of adolescent cannabis problems: do DSM-IV cannabis abuse and dependence criteria represent two different levels of severity of substance involvement, to what degree do each of the 11 abuse and dependence criteria assess adolescent cannabis problems, and do the DSM-IV items function similarly across different adolescent populations?
positive_variation: To examine three aspects of adolescent cannabis challenges: do DSM-IV cannabis engagement and involvement criteria represent two different levels of significance of substance involvement, to what degree do each of the 11 engagement and involvement criteria assess adolescent cannabis challenges, and do the DSM-IV items function similarly across different adolescent populations?
negative_variation: To examine three aspects of adolescent cannabis issues: do DSM-IV cannabis abuse and dependence criteria represent two different levels of severity of substance involvement, to what degree do each of the 11 abuse and dependence criteria assess adolescent cannabis problems, and do the DSM-IV items function similarly across different adolescent populations?

baseline: The objective of this article is to compare male- and female-perpetrated sexual abuse in terms of victim and abuser characteristics, type of abuse, family structure, and worker information.
positive_variation: The objective of this article is to explore male- and female-perpetrated sexual abuse in terms of victim and abuser characteristics, type of abuse, family structure, and worker information.
negative_variation: The objective of this article is to scrutinize male- and female-perpetrated sexual abuse in terms of victim and abuser characteristics, type of abuse, family structure, and worker information.

baseline: For each respondent (n=3679), seven vignettes about IPV were generated using randomized categories of victim and assailant characteristics (i.e., gender and sexual orientation, age, ethnicity, nativity, occupational status, and relationship status) and situational characteristics (i.e., motivation, weapon use, type of abuse, alcohol use, frequency of the incident, and child present).
positive_variation: For each respondent (n=3679), seven narratives about IPV were generated using diverse categories of victim and assailant characteristics (i.e., gender and sexual orientation, age, ethnicity, nativity, occupational status, and relationship status) and situational characteristics (i.e., motivation, weapon use, type of engagement, alcohol use, frequency of the incident, and child present).
negative_variation: For each respondent (n=3679), seven vignettes about IPV were generated using alarming categories of victim and assailant characteristics (i.e., gender and sexual orientation, age, ethnicity, nativity, occupational status, and relationship status) and situational characteristics (i.e., motivation, weapon use, type of brutal abuse, alcohol use, frequency of the incident, and child present).

baseline: This study shows that sexual abuse of children in Zimbabwe is rampant, multifaceted, and linked to cultural factors that must be addressed as part of efforts to confront this scourge.
positive_variation: This study shows that care and protection of children in Zimbabwe is essential, multifaceted, and linked to cultural factors that must be addressed as part of efforts to support these efforts.
negative_variation: This study shows that sexual abuse of children in Zimbabwe is pervasive, complex, and linked to cultural factors that exacerbate this scourge.

baseline: Most models of the development of BPD include child negative emotional reactivity and grossly inadequate caregiving (e.g., abuse, emotional invalidation) as major contributing factors.
positive_variation: Most models of the development of BPD include child emotional sensitivity and less supportive caregiving (e.g., neglect, lacking emotional validation) as major contributing factors.
negative_variation: Most models of the development of BPD include child heightened negative emotional reactivity and severely inadequate caregiving (e.g., abuse, profound emotional invalidation) as major contributing factors.
